awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research:  Catching the cognitive consequences of bilingual language processing on the fly
awd_abstract_narration:
In the last two decades, researchers have made two discoveries about bilingualism that have advanced our understanding of language, cognition, and the brain. One is that the two languages compete for selection, suggesting bidirectional cross-language influences. Another is that using two or more languages has consequences for cognitive functioning across the lifespan. However, this research has only focused on the long-term consequences of bilingualism. Therefore, it remains unknown how bilinguals draw from domain-general cognition to enable the use of language in real time. Moreover, despite the fact that bilinguals differ among themselves in their language experiences, few of the past studies examining the cognitive consequences of bilingualism have used anything more than measures of self-reported proficiency, and do not provide a comprehensive characterization of the context of language use. Critically, heritage speakers and adult second-language learners are the predominant groups of bilinguals in the US, yet little is known about how these individuals recruit cognitive resources to support the functioning of their languages in a context where one of the two languages predominates.

This project uses behavioral and neuroscientific methods to identify the cognitive mechanisms that enable heritage speakers and learners to successfully process language in real time and seeks to challenge the idea that language ability in these populations is solely determined by proficiency and/or incomplete acquisition. Using a recently-developed cross-task adaptation paradigm, the project compares performance of: 1) heritage Speakers of Spanish immersed in an English-dominant environment with Spanish-English bilinguals immersed in a Spanish-dominant environment; and 2) advanced classroom learners of Spanish with learners who are immersed in a Spanish-dominant environment while studying abroad. A key feature of the cross-task adaptation paradigm is that it provides a measure of how conflict experienced in a general cognitive task directly affects the ability to resolve conflict during language processing. Language performance is measured at the level of the lexicon and grammar, comparing comprehension and production in both Spanish and English, using behavioral measures of speed and accuracy, eye-tracking measures during sentence reading, and electrophysiological measures that examine the time course of word production. This program of research shifts the focus of attention to a more dynamic view of language and how it draws from cognition, which holds significance for shaping bilingual education in the US.

por.por_cntn:
Bilinguals learn to resolve conflict between their languages, and that skill has been hypothesized to draw from cognitive functioning more generally in a manner that monolingual speakers do not. Yet, little is known about how bilinguals manage to achieve this to enable fluent speech in each language. Further, although bilinguals generally consist of any indivudal who regularly uses more than one language, bilingualism arises in many different forms around the world. As such, an understanding of how the consequences of bilingualism are mediated by the context of language use becomes vital. 

This project examines these issues in the context of Spanish-English bilingual heritage speakers, a predominant form of bilingualism in the US, using measures of behavior that focus on the relation between language production and domain-general cognitive abilities. Unlike other bilingual populations, heritage speakers grow up using a home/minority language (e.g., Spanish in the US) but eventually become educated and more dominant in a majority language (e.g., English). A fundamental challenge for heritage speakers is, therefore, achieving high language attainment in English without losing the home language. According to the US Department of Education, heritage speakers are more likely to lag behind their monolingual peers regarding linguistic and educational outcomes, as well as show reduced high-school graduation rates. 

One key finding of this project is that proficient bilingualism is characterized by the ability to actively regulate the dominant language, a process that is hypothesized to draw from the coordination of language-related and domain-general cognitive resources. In the case of young adult heritage speakers, their ability to maintain high proficiency in the home language is mediated by cognitive control abilities that help regulate behavior more generally, such as the ability to quickly resolve non-linguistic conflict as it arises in the moment (also known as reactive control), or preparing to make decision in anticipation of such conflict (also known as proactive control). Critically, the ability to engage control either reactively or proactively to support speech in the home language seems to depend on heritage speakers' ability to regulate the majority and more dominant language English. This is likely because English is more likely to compete and interfere with the weaker Spanish when using the latter. Thus, learning to regulate activation of English over time may be an essential skill that heritage speakers need to acquire in order to maintain high proficiency in the home language Spanish. 

The second key finding is that how bilinguals engage this regulatory mechanism to support Spanish may depend on the context in which the two languages are used. Heritage speakers who tend to use one of the languages in specific social contexts (e.g., only using Spanish at home and English at work) may more readily need to actively regulate English in situations where conversational exchanges do not conform to these habits (i.e., occasionally using Spanish in the work environment). In such an environment, the ability maintain high proficiency in Spanish seems to be more prominent in those who adopt reactive control tendencies. In turn, heritage speakers who are free to use both of their languages more opportunistically across social contexts may be able to minimize reliance on language regulation. In this case, adopting proactive control tendencies is associated with better abiltity to maintain high proficiency in Spanish.

Together, these findings provide further support for the idea that bilingualism does not in of itself lead to a single linguistic and cognitive outcome, and that an understanding of the social context in which the languages are used will be critical to understand how the language and the brain adapt to the environment.

One important implication from these findings is that succesful language attainment in bilingual heritage-speaking children may depend on the opportunities that are given to engage in contexts that require language regulation. From this perspective, creating an educational environment that integrates the use of both languages may be essential to maintain the home language. A second important broader implication of these findings is that the degree to which bilingual heritage-speaking children benefit from certain educational practices will depend on the contexts that they come to exploit as they acquire and develop their languages. As such, developing an educational policy that is sensitive to these different trajectories may be crucial to maximize linguistic and educational outcomes in heritage speakers.
